docs.lead_paragraph: A 13-year-old girl who had given birth by herself in her Brooklyn bedroom was charged with criminally negligent homicide yesterday after an autopsy revealed her newborn son had suffocated, police officials said. The teenager had hidden the pregnancy from her family until she gave birth on Sept. 4, investigators said. Early that morning, they said, her stepmother found her stumbling about the family's apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant. At first the girl refused to admit that she had just given birth, officials said, but finally, after coaxing from her stepmother and an uncle, she took them to her room, where she had left the baby wrapped in a towel, the police said. The baby was not breathing, so a city ambulance was called to the apartment, in a four-story brownstone on Kent Avenue, and he was rushed to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center, where he was pronounced dead. Four days later, the medical examiner's office conducted and autopsy and determined that the baby had died from ''asphyxia by smothering,'' officials said. The girl, who suffered from complications associated with the birth, was kept in the hospital for medical care until yesterday, when she was charged and released into the custody of her father and stepmother. Although the baby's death had been ruled a homicide several weeks ago, officials said it had taken time to fully investigate the case and determine the appropriate charge. The teenager, who was not identified by the police because of her age, is not charged with intentionally killing the child. The charge of criminally negligent homicide indicates that investigators determined that the girl had failed to perceive the substantial risk that a reasonable person under the same circumstances would have perceived: that the baby could be killed by being wrapped so completely in a towel. The case will be handled through Family Court, which handles the cases of juvenile offenders. Peter Reinharz, chief of the Family Law Division in the City Law Department, said that in the last five years, there had been a handful of other cases in which very young mothers had been charged with criminally negligent homicide in the death of newborns. A neighbor, Areli Martinez, said yesterday that the girl had been scared to admit her pregnancy and had tried to conceal it from her family and friends. Ms. Martinez said she had not noticed anything because the teenager is big for her age and the pregnancy did not show. ''She was scared,'' she said. ''When she delivered, she delivered alone. It's terrible.'' Investigators said the girl had identified a schoolmate as the father of the child, but it is unclear what school the girl attends. Although police officials said they believed the girl attended Public School 157, officials there said the girl graduated last year. After being admitted to the hospital, the teenager was temporarily put in the custody of the Administration for Children's Services, officials said. She was released to her family yesterday after child welfare investigators found no signs of neglect in the home, said Jennifer Falk, a spokeswoman for the agency.

headline.main: Police Charge 13-Year-Old In Death of Newborn Son

docs.abstract: Thirteen-year-old girl who had given birth by herself is charged with criminally negligent homicide after autopsy revealed newborn son had suffocated; incident took place in Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn; case will be heard in Family Court (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the long struggle over abortion, each side has periodically changed tactics to adapt to an altered political or legal climate. When the anti-abortion movement was stymied in its efforts to outlaw abortion in the 1970's, its allies in Congress succeeded in blocking federal financing for it, a barrier that is still largely in place.
docs.abstract: Analysis of tactical challenge abortion-inducing bill RU-486 poses for anti-abortion forces; notes anti-abortion leaders stress risks of taking pill; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Mitchell Creinin runs an abortion clinic in Pittsburgh and has become something of an expert on the abortion-inducing pill, mifepristone, which was approved for sale in the United States on Thursday. Dr. Creinin has provided the pill to women in research studies, and he has traveled the country giving seminars to doctors who are considering offering the drug to their patients.

headline.main: Many Doctors Find Array of Obstacles To the Abortion Pill

docs.abstract: Doctors interested in prescribing abortion-inducing pill mifepristone are being deterred by array of obstacles; problems include numerous state laws that regulate doctors who provide abortions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Natalie Ferrol spoke of the humiliation of a friend, a frightened young woman who went to have an abortion, but first had to walk past the pickets and protesters outside a clinic. ''It was horrible,'' said Ms. Ferrol, a 22-year-old college student. ''She looked around, and worried that she would see somebody she knew.''

headline.main: Pill Seen As Offering Privacy To Women

docs.abstract: Residents of DeKalb, Ill, college town, comment on Food and Drug Administration approval of abortion-inducing drug RU-486 (mifepristone); see it making abortion much more private matter; number who strongly support legal abortion express reservations about making abortion too easy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a decade of legal and political roadblocks, RU-486 has at last been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for abortions in early pregnancy. The widespread use of this drug is far from certain since it is to be employed only during the first seven weeks of pregnancy, and requires more visits to a doctor than surgical abortion does. But it nonetheless represents a breakthrough for better access to safe, legal abortions, particularly in areas of the country where abortion services are rare or nonexistent. RU-486, also known as mifepristone, when used in combination with misoprostol, an already approved drug, has been proved safe and effective in numerous clinical tests. More than 600,000 European women have used this method, and it now accounts for more than a third of all abortions in France.
docs.abstract: Editorial hails Food and Drug Administration approval of abortion-inducing drug RU-486 (mifepristone); sees breakthrough for better access to safe, legal abortions, particularly where abortion services are rare or nonexistent; urges Congress not to override FDA's decisionl

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday that it had approved the marketing of an abortion-inducing pill, the first alternative to surgical abortion approved in the United States. The pill, a prescription drug, will be available to doctors in about four weeks, its distributor said.

headline.main: DRUG OFFERS MORE PRIVACY, AND COULD RESHAPE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves marketing of abortion-inducing pill mifepristone, or RU-486, first alternative to surgical abortion approved in United States; pill, a prescription drug, will be available to doctors in four weeks, and will allow them to offer abortions outside of specialty clinics; it will allow women to have abortions in privacy of their homes up to seven weeks after their last menstrual period; most women who seek abortions do so later in their pregnancies, but drug has taken on immense symbolic importance for both supporters and opponents of abortion rights; approval of drug brings out sharp contrasts in views on abortion of Vice Pres Al Gore, who supports FDA move, and Gov George W Bush, who says FDA is wrong; Dr Jane E Henney, FDA commissioner, says decision was based on persuasive data showing that drug is safe and effective; says politics played no role in decision; chart; map (L)
docs.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday that it had approved the marketing of an abortion-inducing pill, the first alternative to surgical abortion approved in the United States.    The pill, a prescription drug, will be available to...

docs.lead_paragraph: An abortion using mifepristone, or RU-486, takes place in three steps. First, in a doctor's office, a woman takes three pills of mifepristone, which blocks the action of progesterone, a hormone required to maintain a pregnancy. She will return to the doctor's office 36 to 48 hours later to take two tablets of a second drug, misoprostol, a prostaglandin or hormonelike substance that will make her uterus contract, expelling the fetal tissue.

headline.main: Use of Mifepristone in Abortion Is a 3-Step Procedure

docs.abstract: Abortion using mifepristone, or RU-486, takes place in three steps; process described (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Abortion rights supporters celebrated a long-sought victory today, with the Food and Drug Administration's approval of the abortion pill RU-486, but acknowledged that it could be an exceedingly fragile one. Abortion opponents denounced the administration and the agency for pushing through a drug ''that will take lives instead of saving them,'' as Senator Tim Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, put it. They vowed to keep fighting, legislatively and politically.
docs.abstract: Abortion rights supporters celebrate long-sought victory with Food and Drug Administration's approval of abortion pill RU-486, but acknowledge victory could be short-lived if Republicans win in November; abortion opponents denounce Clinton administration and FDA for pushing through drug that takes lives, and they vow to keep fighting legislatively and politically; FDA ruling highlights stakes for November's election, given stark differences between two parties on abortion issue; with White House, House and perhaps Senate up for grabs, along with possibility of reshaping of Supreme Court by next president, election could have major implications for federal abortion policy (M)
